title: Hungarian Ornithological and Nature Conservation Society
text:
The Hungarian Ornithological and Nature Conservation Society (<a href="Hungarian%20language">Hungarian</a>: "Magyar Madártani és Természetvédelmi Egyesület") (MME), also known as BirdLife Hungary, is a non-profit <a href="ornithology">ornithological</a> and <a href="Conservation%20%28ethic%29">nature conservation</a> organisation founded in <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> in 1974. Its mission is to protect wild birds and help preserve <a href="biodiversity">biodiversity</a>. It has about 10,000 members, employs 26 staff, and is the Hungarian partner organisation of <a href="BirdLife%20International">BirdLife International</a>. Since 1991 it has published the journal "Ornis Hungarica".
History.
MME was formed in 1974 with 200 founding members. Initially it focussed on population surveys of <a href="threatened%20species">threatened species</a>, later expanding to promotion of, and lobbying for, nature conservation, as well as education and conservation fieldwork programs.
Activities.
Animals for which MME has been involved in conservation programs include the <a href="Vipera%20ursinii">meadow viper</a>, <a href="imperial%20eagle">imperial eagle</a>, <a href="saker%20falcon">saker falcon</a>, <a href="great%20bustard">great bustard</a>, and <a href="white%20stork">white</a> and <a href="black%20stork">black stork</a>s. Since 1976 MME has also operated the Hungarian Bird Ringing Centre.
"Ornis Hungarica".
 Ornis Hungarica is a biannual <a href="Peer%20review">peer-reviewed</a> <a href="open%20access">open access</a> <a href="scientific%20journal">scientific journal</a> covering <a href="ornithology">ornithology</a> published by the society. It was established in 1991 and is edited by <a href="Tibor%20Cs%C3%B6rg%C5%91">Tibor Csörgő</a>. It concentrates in particular on the <a href="bird">bird</a>s of Central Europe and Hungary.
